facts: A tempo mark like Allegro or Largo tells performers the general speed of the music.
A crescendo means the music gradually gets louder, while a decrescendo or diminuendo means it gradually gets softer.
A key signature uses sharps or flats at the start of a staff to show what notes are usually altered in a piece.
A time signature, such as 4/4 or 3/4, tells how many beats are in each measure and what kind of note gets one beat.
A rest is a musical symbol that shows a silence for a specific length of time, just like notes show sound.
Staccato means notes are played short and detached, while legato means they are played smoothly connected.
A chord is two or more notes played together, and three-note chords called triads are some of the most common in Western music.
